# Upload Media Assets

Media assets like images, videos, and graphics are the visual heart of your press release. Here you learn how to upload, organize, and prepare them for distribution.

## Why Good Media Assets Matter

- **Higher Publication Rate**: Journalists prefer releases with professional images
- **Better Placement**: Articles with images are placed more prominently
- **Social Media**: Images increase engagement on social media
- **Complete Press Material**: You deliver everything journalists need

## Where Do I Upload Media Assets?

### Option 1: In Data Tab

1. Open your project
2. Go to **Data** tab
3. Click into **Media Assets** folder
4. Click **Upload** (cloud icon)

### Option 2: Directly from Press Release

1. Go to **Press Release** tab
2. In **Media Attachments** section
3. Click **+ Add Media**
4. Select **Upload**

> **Note:** Both ways lead to the same media pool. Files you upload are automatically available in the project.

## Uploading Single File

### Step 1: Open Upload Dialog

1. Go to **Data ‚Üí Media Assets**
2. Click **Upload**

### Step 2: Select File

1. Click **Select File**
2. Choose a file from your computer
3. Click **Open**

### Step 3: Complete Upload

1. File is uploaded (progress bar)
2. After completion, it appears in the file list

## Uploading Multiple Files Simultaneously

### Method 1: Multi-Select

1. Click **Upload**
2. Select multiple files:
   - **Windows**: Ctrl + Click on each file
   - **Mac**: Cmd + Click on each file
3. Click **Open**
4. All files are uploaded sequentially

### Method 2: Drag & Drop

1. Open File Explorer/Finder next to CeleroPress
2. Select multiple files
3. Drag them onto the **Media Assets** folder or into the upload area
4. Release mouse
5. Upload starts automatically

> **Tip:** Drag & drop is the fastest method for many files!

## Supported File Formats

### Images

**Recommended:**
- **JPG**: For photos (compressed, small file sizes)
- **PNG**: For graphics with transparency, screenshots
- **WebP**: Modern alternative to JPG (even smaller files)

**Other formats:**
- GIF (animations)
- SVG (vector graphics)
- TIFF (uncompressed, very large)

### Videos

- **MP4**: Standard for web videos (recommended)
- **MOV**: Apple format (also supported)
- **AVI**: Older format (works, but large files)

### Documents

- **PDF**: For additional documents (data sheets, etc.)
- **DOCX, XLSX, PPTX**: Office documents

### Archives

- **ZIP, RAR**: Compressed folders

> **Important:** Maximum file size per upload is 100 MB. For larger videos, use an external link.

## Optimizing Images (before upload)

### Reducing File Size

Too large images:
- Slow down upload
- Burden journalists' email inboxes
- Cost unnecessary storage space

**Recommended sizes:**
- **Press photos**: Max. 2-3 MB
- **Social media images**: Max. 1 MB
- **Screenshots**: Max. 500 KB

**Compression tools:**
- **TinyPNG** (https://tinypng.com) ‚Äì reduces PNG/JPG by 70% without visible quality loss
- **Squoosh** (https://squoosh.app) ‚Äì browser tool with many options
- **ImageOptim** (Mac) or **Caesium** (Windows) ‚Äì desktop apps

### Adjusting Resolution

**Recommended resolutions:**
- **Print quality**: 300 DPI, min. 2000px width
- **Online media**: 72 DPI, 1200-1920px width
- **Social media**: 1080px width

**Too large resolutions:**
‚ùå 6000 x 4000 px (24 megapixel photo directly from camera)
‚úÖ 2400 x 1600 px (sufficient for print and online)

### Optimizing File Names

Rename before upload:

‚ùå Bad:
- `IMG_1234.jpg`
- `Screenshot 2024-01-15 at 14.23.45.png`
- `Image1.jpg`

‚úÖ Good:
- `Product-Name-Variant-A-Portrait.jpg`
- `Team-Photo-Management-2024.jpg`
- `Logo-Company-RGB-Transparent.png`

**Advantages:**
- Easier to find in file list
- More professional in emails to journalists
- Better SEO when images are published online

## Folder Structure for Media

### Creating Subfolders

For better organization:

1. Go to **Data ‚Üí Media Assets**
2. Click **Create Folder**
3. Enter a name (e.g., "Product Photos", "Team Photos", "Logos")

**Example structure:**

```
üìÅ Media Assets
  üìÅ Product Photos
    üìÅ Variant A
    üìÅ Variant B
  üìÅ Team Photos
  üìÅ Logos
    Logo-RGB.png
    Logo-CMYK.png
    Logo-BW.png
  üìÅ Event Photos
  üìÅ Screenshots
```

### Uploading Files into Folders

**Method 1:** Drag & drop directly onto folder
1. Drag files onto desired folder
2. Upload occurs directly into this folder

**Method 2:** Navigate into folder first
1. Click on folder
2. Then upload

## Editing Images

After upload, you can edit images directly in CeleroPress.

### Opening Image Editor

1. Click on an image in the file list
2. Preview opens
3. Click **Edit** (pencil icon)

### Available edits:

- **Crop**: Select image section
- **Rotate**: 90¬∞ left/right
- **Brightness/Contrast**: Adjust
- **Filters**: Black & white, sepia, etc.
- **Add text**: Labels

> **Tip:** For professional edits, use external tools (Photoshop, Affinity Photo, GIMP) and upload the finished image.

## Selecting Images for Press Release

### Choosing from Media Pool

1. Go to **Press Release** tab
2. In **Media Attachments** section
3. Click **+ Add Media**
4. Select **From Project Media**
5. Choose images from pool
6. Click **Add**

Selected images will be:
- Displayed in press release
- Sent as attachments in email to journalists
- Visible in approval center for clients

### Setting Key Visual

The **Key Visual** is the main image of the press release:

1. In **Media Attachments** section
2. Hover over an image
3. Click **‚≠ê Mark as Key Visual**

The key visual will be:
- Placed prominently in press release
- Displayed in email header
- Used on social media (if activated)

## Using Images from Library

When reusing images (e.g., logos, team photos):

### Importing from Library

1. Go to **Press Release ‚Üí Media Attachments**
2. Click **+ Add Media ‚Üí From Library**
3. Select images from global media library
4. Click **Import**

> **Advantage:** Images are not stored twice but referenced.

## Metadata and Image Rights

### Adding Metadata

1. Click on an image
2. In preview dialog: Click **Edit Details**
3. Add:
   - **Title**: Description of image
   - **Alt text**: For accessibility and SEO
   - **Copyright**: Photographer/source
   - **Usage rights**: "Released for editorial use"

**Example:**
- **Title**: CEO Max Mustermann in front of new company headquarters
- **Alt text**: Max Mustermann standing in front of modern office building
- **Copyright**: ¬© Photographer Name / Company Name
- **Usage rights**: Released for editorial use in connection with this press release

### Why Metadata Matters

- **Legal security**: Journalists know if they can use the image
- **Professional appearance**: Shows you pay attention to details
- **SEO**: Search engines index images better
- **Accessibility**: Screen readers can describe images

## Avoiding Common Mistakes

### Mistake 1: Too Large Files

‚ùå 15 MB photo directly from camera
‚úÖ 2 MB optimized photo (TinyPNG)

**Consequences of large files:**
- Slow upload
- Emails blocked by spam filters
- Journalists cannot open attachments

### Mistake 2: Wrong Formats

‚ùå TIFF files (uncompressed, huge)
‚ùå BMP files (outdated)
‚úÖ JPG for photos, PNG for graphics

### Mistake 3: Bad File Names

‚ùå `IMG_1234.jpg`, `Image1.jpg`
‚úÖ `Product-Launch-Press-Photo-2024.jpg`

### Mistake 4: No Image Rights Specified

Journalists **must** know:
- Who is the photographer?
- Can they use the image?

**Always specify:**
- Copyright: ¬© Photographer's name
- Usage rights: "Free reprint with credit to photographer"

### Mistake 5: Only One Image

‚ùå A single product shot
‚úÖ 3-5 different images:
- Product photo (portrait)
- Product photo (landscape)
- Product in use
- Team photo or portrait
- Detail shot

**Why multiple images?**
- Journalists have different layouts (portrait vs. landscape)
- More choice = higher chance of publication

## Best Practices for Press Photos

### 1. Professional Quality

‚úÖ Well-lit, sharp, high resolution
‚ùå Blurry, too dark, pixelated

### 2. Offer Different Formats

- **Portrait** (e.g., 2000 x 3000 px)
- **Landscape** (e.g., 3000 x 2000 px)
- **Square** (e.g., 2000 x 2000 px) for social media

### 3. Contextual Images

Not just the product, but:
- Product in use ("People using product")
- Team context ("People behind the product")
- Environment/atmosphere

### 4. Authenticity

‚úÖ Real employees, real situations
‚ùå Obvious stock photos

### 5. Post-processing

- Light color and contrast adjustments: ‚úÖ
- Exaggerated filters and effects: ‚ùå

## Frequently Asked Questions

**How many images should I upload?**

Optimal: 3-5 high-quality images. Better fewer, but better quality.

**Can I send videos as attachments?**

Yes, but note:
- Videos over 50 MB: Better provide as link (YouTube, Vimeo)
- In email, only attach video link instead of large file

**Can I use stock photos?**

Yes, if you own the license. But:
- Inform journalists about the source
- Authentic photos work better
- Many media prefer original material

**What do I do if I don't have image rights?**

Without image rights, you **cannot** use the photo. Options:
- Ask photographer for permission
- Take (commission) own photos
- Use royalty-free photos (Unsplash, Pexels)

**Are images automatically compressed on upload?**

Yes, CeleroPress automatically compresses images for web optimization. But: Still upload already optimized images for best quality.

## Tips for Efficient Work

### Tip 1: Use Bulk Upload

Upload all images for a project in one step (drag & drop).

### Tip 2: Prepare Folders

Create folders **before** upload, then upload directly into the right folder.

### Tip 3: Optimize Images Externally

Use TinyPNG before uploading. Saves time and storage space.

### Tip 4: Naming Conventions

Establish a system:
- `[Project]-[Type]-[Variant]-[Format].jpg`
